review_title: Poor Pay, Poor Morale, Zero Loyalty
pros: Great Holidays, campus is a beautiful place to work.
cons: The pay is at least 20% below market value. Faculty making 150K+++++++ get their 10% increase over three years, which believe me they deserve, however staff making 30K+ get 3%. There's an article in the Queen's Gazette about custodial staff having to use the food bank to feed their families. Absolutely disgusting that a "top tier" institution pays the people at the bottom so little they can't feed their families. Long standing employees are leaving in droves, over worked, burnt out, and not compensated. This place is a revolving door. The only thing keeping me here is the time off I've accrued from devoting 20 years of my life. I'm no longer proud to say I work here.

review_title: Very nice place for graduate students
job_title: Research Assistant/Graduate Student in Kingston, ON
pros: Queen's Physics Department is a positive and competitive place for graduate students. We have frequent and regular seminars and speakers are on average top notch.  You have to take initiatives though for whatever you want and there are generally enough resources and staff and faculty are very supportive. Queen's have services that I have made use of and they are in general very good quality. For example, writing centre (helps you writing an essay or thesis), career centre (provides workshops on cover letter, resume, interview and resources and books), library (user friendly and supportive), and nice health, counselling and disability services.
cons: There are not enough choices for graduate courses each year in Physics department.  The building itself is very old and the design does not engage interactions among graduate students at different groups. Graduate students' offices are scattered through the entire building. Students sit at different floors hardly meet unless they TA together or go to the same seminars.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kingston, ON
pros: Queen's houses some cutting-edge scientific research (can't speak to the arts or social science programs), and excellent facilities for teaching and learning.  Kingston is also a very nice city, with something for everyone.
cons: Dealing with any of the central administration is always terribly inefficient, in my experience. For example, I tried last year to create a room booking for a weekly seminar and waited for two weeks for a response. When they finally responded, they simply said that the room booking could not be accommodated in the building I requested, without offering any alternatives. This was untenable and inefficient, to say the least. After going through this process for a month, I simply booked a smaller room within my department for the seminar. I have experienced several similar issues with people in the Registrar's office, and with Queen's Community Housing.

review_title: So happy to be working for Queen's University in my home town of Kingston
pros: This is a great collaborative environment where people appreciate good work.  Since starting here in January 2015 I have worked with multiple leaders who were having difficulty finding good people and when I was able to offer assistance, they were very appreciative.  I also really enjoy the ability to use the athletic centre during my lunch hour, which is right here on campus.  Queen's campus is such a great environment to work in.
cons: I work in a centralized service role for Queen's and the university is a very decentralized environment, so that can make my job a challenge.  I'm not sure this is exactly a con, but it is something I had to adjust to.

pros: Working closely with a great group of execs who share the same interest and are willing to help each other achieve their tasks on time. It was great to see the impact on students after each event that was held by ResSoc and know that our hard work has paid off. It is completely ran by students so it is easy to relate to other employees
cons: Because it is completely student run, it sometimes lack the professionalism of an actual company. Sometimes students are busy with academics and do not prioritize the responsibilities of their position which can be difficult for the rest of the team

review_title: Some areas are hotbeds for harassment
pros: Some departments are OK. Always ask staff who work there before applying.  Most long-time staff know where the "problem areas" are. Queen's provides tuition support for both children of staff and staff.
cons: There are horrendous conditions in some departments where managers/directors behave like malignant narcissists. There is no point in complaining to HR about harassment or in trying to move to a different area. HR knows all about the problems in certain departments. They don't report the truth, they whitewash the situation and undermine/'gaslight' complainants.

pros:
- There's lots of different types of equipment to learn about
- The historic buildings are nice to look at
- Some friendly and knowledgeble people to learn from
- Kingston is a great city
cons:
- The average age is about 50. No young people.
- Most people are in retirement mode, who say things like "it won't be my problem soon."
- The department is severely understaffed
- There's a lack of funding for necessary maintenance projects
- There's no policies or procedures, in a department that's been around for a while
- Everyone's very busy and rarely help out one another unless you ask

pros:

- Worked on course development as well as marking work
- Flexible hours
- Good job to have while being a student
-Better comp than other part-time student jobs
cons:
- Long hours in the post-exam season
- Experience very much depends on the professor you work with
- Undergrad TAs are paid less for doing the same work as Masters TAs (e.g. marking).
- Pay period is monthly

job_title: Graduate Student and Research Assist in Kingston, ON
pros:
- gain more experience in a particular field of interest
- collaborate with fellow research students to contribute more
- attend conferences and workshops which gain insights into the ongoing and future work in the field
- Being a grad student opens up the possibility of getting into the teaching field
cons:
- must have a good supervisor in order to work positively
- it takes a long time to find a problem which needs to be solved
- for those who are going to the industry writing papers and attending conferences may not be relevant

review_title: High quality research with knowledgeable and bright individuals
pros:
Professors are knowledgeable, bright, helpful, and supportive.
Working in a lab with several grad students and other academics creates the perfect environment for interesting discussions about ideas, projects, and life in general.
Highly qualified network of researchers available to provide help in multiple matters.
Queen's offers multiple opportunities for engaging in healthy and socially active lifestyles.
Queen's name on a CV seems to be well appreciated.
cons:
Competition for positions at Queen's is very tough.
High quality comes with the cost of a high work load.
Queen's throws multiple demonstrations and open houses to attract new students and attract donations over the year. Taking part of so many events can become very time consuming and routine.

review_title: An excellent school to pursue knowledge
pros: Queen's is an excellent school with a lot of history and school spirit. The professors here are excellent in that they aren't just the top professors in Canada, but are also some of the best teachers in the world. They emphasize on your education and help you towards achieving your goals. They are always available out of class hours and really go the extra mile in helping you with explanation of assignments and projects.
cons: The life in Kingston can be borning, and quiet. If you are an extrovert, you might get bored.

review_title: Great place to research if you get the right professor
pros:
- Some professors will let you write and first-author a paper as an undergraduate, this is amazing for a resume
 - PARTEQ (the technology commercialization arm) will help you commercialize any IP you create
 - Overall, lots of opportunity if you work hard and smart (i.e. work on the right projects with the people who will help you get ahead)
cons:
- Compensation isn't great compared to industry, but good compared to other academic pursuits
 - Senior management at the university have very little idea of what's going on

review_title: Generally positive - but room for improvement
pros:
good colleagues - who genuinely care about their work and about the students.
opportunity for transfer and for advancement - sometimes advancement decisions seem more political than anything, but that's not unique to this employer
cons:
not all depts are equally 'healthy' - there are some units where staff are disengaged and going through the motions

the job grading system is uneven - same job in different depts can be graded very differently

review_title: Fairly good university to live at and work in.
pros: As a grad student, there is very little work you need to do to maintain satisfactory performance. And with the new Queen's centre coming soon, there will finally be good athletic facilities.
cons: The bureaucracy can be kind of annoying. Kingston is kind of a dirty city with slum-like housing that is surprisingly expensive.

pros: The Queen's Sociology department was a place of communal aid and dedication to student support. If one person was not able to fill a students' needs, another person came in to help right away. This made a good and cohesive team with few issues that came up unexpectedly.
cons: A lot of pressure was put on one person to spearhead and lead a large group of new teaching assistants who did not have a lot of formal training in teaching. More experienced educators had to step in place, but without additional hours or compensation for this work, although it ultimately helped the entirety of the department in its endeavors.

pros: It was a very high-energy, enthusiastic, positive atmosphere. It was very inclusive and considerate of people's diverse backgrounds and different needs. Very active job, doing a lot of fun things. High opportunity to meet new people.
cons: A lot of time commitment required. Due to the high number of new people you work with, there are various conflicts that come up  -so people working in this position must be are skilled in interpersonal awareness, conflict management and problem solving. No pay.

review_title: Positive overall experience, culture defined by adaptability and success
pros:
Amazing opportunities to expand your professional network
Exposure to corporate opportunities
Talented and driven student group
cons:
Large, university environment... sometimes hierarchical
Lack of communication/partnership between departments

pros: Worked as an engineering graduate student, supervisor was generous, supportive, and extremely capable within his field. The rest of the faculty was also fantastic to work with.
cons: Like many Universities, work can be bogged down by administration. Recently pulled a neat IT amalgamation stunt that was poorly planned out without plans to support some existing software and hardware support. IT themselves were sympathetic and helpful as they could be, obviously a management choice.

pros: Opportunity to meet other students. Freedom to explore your project in many directions; independence.
cons: Experience depends largely on your supervisor. If they are nice and caring, you will have a great experience, even if you choose to not continue in research. If they are bad, you will be expected to work full-time hours in the lab despite not receiving adequate compensation, you may have to stay beyond 2 years just to finish your degree, etc.

pros: Queen's offers a lot of perks such as Thrive, a series of wellness events annually on campus, $5 lunches on Fridays and a great series of workshops and certificate courses through HR.
cons: There is a huge silo effect throughout the university. Many departments have their own procedures and protocols and often they don't communicate with each other. There are also some departments that make it difficult to use campus resources if you don't have a connection.

pros: Everyone lives within minutes of each other. You really feel as if you've entered a very cohesive and loving community the moment you step foot in this place. The friends you make here last a lifetime! Other than that, classes are typically quite engaging, and professors are typically of very high calibre both in their respective research fields and in teaching skills.
cons: Prepare to work hard! If you really want to make the most of your experience, you have to get involved with various extra-curriculars, and invest time in getting to know your professors!

pros: The students that I worked with were really great. The pay for the position was fantastic. The facilities for holding office hours and teaching students were great and really helped facilitate learning. Finally, the hours were flexible and fit nicely around my schedule.
cons: There was absolutely nothing to complain about. All around it was an amazing experience. The only drawback was that there were only a few summer teaching assistant positions that were available.

pros: friendly environment, benefits and perks are worth it, one of the top universities in Canada. Everyone works together well with a positive mental attitude.
cons: Management staff not good at giving clear expectations and descriptors of negative feedback.

review_title: As good as can be expected for grad school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kingston, ON
pros: TA positions have an outstanding hourly rate, many good people within the department.
cons: The hourly rate is meaningless, since they tell you how much work to complete and how many hours you've been budgeted for. For example, having 3 minutes budgeted per 10-20 page lab report to be marked. Many of the usual factors associated with being a graduate student. Health and benefits not worth much. Any services I used capped out so early that I rarely got out of it how much I paid in.

pros: Still has a good reputation and job security.Does not tolerate any kind of discrimination and has a great pension plan.
cons: Sucess and power has changet the mission of this once top-rated university.It has lost it's focus of being the best educator and is now more interested in it's image.It no longer looks out to help or support it's alumnaes.

review_title: My experience at Queen's has been good and frustrating at the same time.
pros: Some better aspects are unionized administrative support staff, ongoing openings for internal and external candidates, friendly staff, working in one of Canada's most prestigious universities.
cons: Internal and external jobs are posted at the same time. As people retire, positions are not being filled, and many lay offs over the last two years. Nepotism is common in the physical plant department. Job vacancies are rarely permanent full time - mostly part time or contract positions.

pros: Kingston is a really nice to place to live. The campus is breathtakingly beautiful and downtown is close by. Everybody is very kind and helpful. The community is very tight knit.
cons: There are not a lot of big companies in the local area, but Queen's reputation makes up for it, as many large firms come to recruit here. Tuition and rent can be very expensive. A lot of programs seemed to be enrolling too many students to give each one the individual attention they need.

pros:
- Benefits are good and easy to access 
- There is a lot of opportunity for promotion or to move around to find job suitability
- Management understands the importance of a good work/life balance and worked to ensure that I had a comfortable balance
- Working environment is great and the campus has a lot to offer outside of the working hours
cons: As a higher education institution, there is an inherent imbalance between faculty and staff that sometimes can hinder your ability to perform your work

pros: Designed, built, tested and submitted an electrical engineering project to the university patent office. Professors were knowledgeable and helpful. A good range of courses and backgrounds to learn frmo.
cons: The toughest part was to gather initial funding. You can do anything, but to do anything you must do all the research, preparation, and meetings yourself. Approval processes could be better streamlined

review_title: AMS Jobs are great for students

cons: There were times when patrons were less than friendly or cooperative, and made the experience a very unpleasant one. Other than that, great experience.

pros: Benefits, course bonuses, vacation, great people to work with. Relaxed and break when you want. Really there is not much more to say. Little job security no matter where you work at Queens except if you are a prof.
cons: Profs can do what they want. No one is held accountable for anything. Low pay for many of support staff. Very elitist place. Very snobby and class oriented. As boring as can be

pros: none. none. none. none. none.

When I would complain to the manager, they would tell me to give my shift to another coworker and I would lose my hours for the week. There is no sense of security for their workers and when you bring the problem to the manager, they don't care.

cons: Sometimes I have long hours and the pay isn't the best, but I receive pretty good benefits. My kids get taken care of.

Somewhat flexible hours
Nice facilities

Experience dependent on professor--I had an overbearing professor who lacked the ability to communicate effectively to myself and the rest of the staff. 
Also, there were points in time when I had absolutely no work because I met my deadlines months in advance.

pros: Great environment and amazing people. You can always find the help you require. The HR staff works great to support any needs of a student employee.
cons: It is not the easiest to find openings like this one. Most research related jobs are given internally to students so we do not see a lot of outside talent.

pros: The hours are consistent with a minimum of 2 shifts which is great for full time students, The midnight shifts are good for people who need extra money but can't get out of an 9 to 5 job.
cons: The job is very stressful and can get very intimidating during peak periods. Although the training is efficient, each supervisor has a different idea on what the best approach is. If you keep to yourself, it's a good side job.

pros: Queen's offers excellent Compensation, Benefits, a competitive Work and Life Balance, and has great Culture and Values. The city of Kingston is a great place to live and work. The professors are amazing.
cons: The career opportunities to move up the ladder seem to be few and far between and or based on "who you know". Although beautiful Kingston is very close minded and does not offer a lot of selection for events and activities.

job_title: Student Athlete Academic Mentor in Kingston, ON

cons: There is some bureaucracy as it is still a public institution

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kingston, ON

They fully support and  encourage you to come up with your own approaches to solving research problems,and give adequate time to do so.
cons: None, except that the snow in Kingston can sometimes be a downer.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Kingston, ON

cons:
- if you love big cities this might not be the place for you
- if you want to go into industry, depending on the program, you need to go out of your way in some programs to get internships prior to graduating

pros: I really enjoyed my time at Queen's, as a grad student, TA, and RA. My advisor (Ram Murty) was extraordinary, and members of the mathematics department were uniformly warm and supportive. The students in all of my classes were more interested than they have been at other universities at which I've taught, and this made for an enjoyable classroom experience.
cons: Some graduate student offices do not have windows.

pros: I had lots of flexibility in how I delivered and structured my lessons. My course coordinator was supportive and knowledgeable.
cons: Course could be disorganized, and the high degree of responsibility for TAs to determine which teaching material is relevant led to inconsistencies in lessons between lab sessions.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kingston, ON

cons: I had colleague that I frequented and they lacked common sense. One person was enough to ruin the experience.

pros: Vibrant campus and great faculty. Challenging classes however, and relatively small class sizes per course. Plenty of extracurriculars to take advantage of.
cons: Challenging classes and relatively small campus. Not much to do in the Kingston community. Campus buildings are quite deteriorated with age.

job_title: Engineering Research Assistant in Kingston, ON
pros: Great flexibility. Work at your own pace. Work on the project YOU want. Pay covers living expenses.
cons: Choose a good thesis supervisor. Some have trouble, so know what your getting into.

pros: Good experience. You get a big institution name on your resume. Nice campus, good work-life balance. People around you that are not on the board are very nice.
cons: Too much politics. You are restricted in the ways you can go about your work. Not much diversity around the campus.

pros: Beautiful campus right beside the lake. Queen's has a very live spirit and atmosphere which gives you energy to work.
cons: The financial support is minimal while the work load is quite high at the same time. Graduate studies seems to be second-degree citizen.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kingston, ON

cons: There weren't a lot of research assistant opportunities for grad students in social sciences

pros: Queen's facilitated a great working environment among many smart and driven colleagues. As a research assistant, hours were very adaptable and flexible. Doing research also opened many opportunities in industry and academia.
cons: Working as a research assistant sometimes was a unstructured environment which can be a con for some people. Pay wasn't great but was fair.

pros: Great school and good place to work. Lots of committed kids who just want to make a difference.
cons: Everything is a process and needs to get approved. Very slow to change or to react to events.

pros:

review_title: Good place for part-time work (if you are a student)

- Management not too hard on employees
cons:

review_title: Rudderless ship that needs to be righted
pros: Flexible hours and a beautiful campus to work on. For the most part minimal supervision allows for a relaxing work environment.
cons: An overly bureaucratic environment where creativity is supported only if it has been done before. The institution seems rudderless, and has lost track of its roots.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Kingston, ON
pros: I love Queen's U. enviornment. Both academic departments and other departments are very clinet-friendly.  It has promisng non-academic career opportunities. Benefits are great as well.
cons: I think one of the big cons is that it is located in a relatively small city

review_title: A very good place to learn

cons: Salary was low as it was funded only from NSERC scholarshp and supervisor funding.

pros: the instrumentations are well equipped even though some of them are not owned by single laboratory but shared with the other labs sometimes with the other departments.
cons: the cafeteria spaces in the campus are quite small and always full of undergraduate students, also their foods are quite expensive.

pros: Pension and benefits provided by the university are generous and work/life balance is promoted in most departments.
cons: Culture. Everyone counting the days until retirement. Little ability to build your career. Low comparative pay. Senior administration is paid 4-6x that of mid-level management.

pros: Kingston is an amazing place to live and provides a great work environment. There are opportunities for collaboration across departments
cons: I find the computer science program to be outdated and not effectively preparing new grads to the work industry

review_title: A great place for graduate training
pros: Queen's University is a world renowned research institute.  They have incredible facilities and a huge number of expert faculty.
cons: Like many universities this is a large institution. It can be hard to find access to all the resources you may need.

pros: They provide easy commuting, nice environment and good work-life balance. Gym is very good in quality and price. Easy to obtain scientific literature.
cons: They are very cheap on benefits for Postdocs (no dental plan, no support for daycare) . HR department is very slow in responding.

pros: Excellence in education, great opportunity for development, multicultural environment.
cons: Too expensive, not offering too many opportunities for working after degree completion, very academic-oriented and poor connection to private sector.

review_title: Great opportunity to work in interdisciplinary research environment in graduate school.
pros:
- small community (many researchers know each other)
- great environment for interdisciplinary work
- professors take their educator role seriously
cons:
- since it is a small community, there is a lot of independent work
- HR is difficult

pros: good staff and environment, provide good system for students to share and study
cons: nothing in Kingston, so the only entertainment is to throw a party in weekends, and students usually get drunk then

pros: Hours are extremely flexible and worked to fit around your schedule, all employers understand that academics come first
cons: Pay is minimum wage with no raise regardless how many years you work, set amount of hours means no option to increase/decrease them

job_title: School of Business in Kingston, ON
pros: lots of opportunity and a variety of jobs, some buildings are beautiful, energy and optimism of the best students in Canada

review_title: Opened my eyes to the relationship and differences between Government, Private industry and Academia
pros: Fascinating work with highly educated and motivated people. The benefits are fantastic including access to fitness facilities, tuition benefit for yourself and dependents, medical plan with 100% prescription coverage, Christmas break shut down in addition to vacation time etc...
cons:
The salaries are very low as compared to other employers.  
While the majority of people were fantastic to work with there were a strong contingent who had graduated from there and have spent their entire careers there with no outside experience. Those individuals have moved up the chain together and are inhibiting true growth and progress due to lack of a broader perspective. The phrase "we've always done it this way" should be a red flag for upper management but in this case they make up a significant portion of the upper management.

review_title: Great place to work, as long as you can put up with some negatives...
pros:
- Summer hours (one less hour per day from June 1st to September 1st)
- Christmas-New Year shutdown of approximately 6 days
- Increasing access/days to additional annual leave with seniority
- Free education or courses for immediate family
- Great place to start for University students
cons:
- "Education is king" mindset, the more education you have - the 'better employee you are' mentality discourages new ideas of 'less educated' to thrive
- Lack of transparency in decision making
- Can be very bureaucratic/red tape
- Parking is expensive on-campus
- Not all teams have similar working conditions, some groups are managed by tyrant directors / managers (HR where are you? 360-evaluations not transparent)
- Reorganization / job cuts and budget cuts are very stressful to employees
- Constant never-ending "Strategic Planning" sessions are counterintuitive and not well managed

review_title: University of Ottawa, a bilingual university in the capital of Canada
pros: It's a Bilingual environment (both English and French), it's a great location (close to downtown Ottawa), working with a diverse student population is fun, it's a dynamic environment that is always changing, the pay is good with regular increases, there is a good benefits package, opportunity for advancement exists
cons: Contract employees are at a great disadvantage compared to permanent. The union was only created last year and they are still working on creating a more just balance between employees. Parking is difficult to come by and is difficult because of the downtown location. Because it is such a large employer bureacracy is sometimes an issue

review_title: Great employer but needs to be more flexible
pros: Great benefits! 3 weeks vacation to start and the university is closed  Christmas and New years and you get paid during that holiday. My college are amazing people
cons: Not open to working from home. Very rigid on the schedule. Its a 9-5 job with not a lot of flexibility. Change takes a LOT of time to happen. The management team had a Very old mentally. Managers dont always have good people skills

pros: Flexible working schedules are given to employee. Supportive staff and management makes it easier to work. In addition to this high hourly pay makes it easier to concentrate on the studies.
cons: Even though work hours are flexible, individual commitment is very important. In case of emergencies it is hard to change this schedules (but not impossible). It is a competitive job as the availability is less if an individual does not have funding from university.

review_title: Great place if a little too stiff
pros: Universities are always stimulating places to be. Such is the case with uOttawa. As an analyst, I had the chance to work with multiple stakeholders in management all committed to the betterment of the institution. Employment conditions are great with generous salaries and a very comprehensive benefits package.
cons: There is something about large institutions that make them hard to turn around when obstacles are in sight. uOttawa tends to be a little stiff and not nimble enough to face the fast changing higher education landscape in Canada.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ottawa, ON
pros: The workload was typically fair and reasonable for the compensation.  Expectations from the beginning of the semester were usually well communicated.
cons: The assignment of TA positions and the payroll were a nightmare.  Assignments came late, often weeks into the semester, and were assigned sporadically, not based on the area of expertise of the teaching assistant.  I have been paid months late or been missing part of my paycheque on more than one occasion.

pros: Teaching science is fun, mostly the administration respects the TA if a student is complaining about grades
cons: If teaching a lab course, there WILL be mandatory unpaid overtime. There is no physical way to mark all of the labs to the assigned standards without going overtime. I believe the university is working on fixing this but it's not gone yet.

review_title: satisfactory experience working as a research assistant while attending law school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Ottawa, ON
pros: I worked as a graduate research assistant for one of the law professors while attending law school. The work was very interesting - assisting case law research work for a professor who was writing a book on a legal topic. The professor was helpful in providing directions and feedback.
cons: There is none. The work was very interesting, the schedule very flexible and the professor provided timely feedback and a lot of encouragement.

pros: You have very experienced researcher here, and they love about talking their research. If you want to do serious science here, this is a good place to be. The research environment is very collaborative, almost all labs are connected and equipments seems to be shared freely. There is always some nice scientific talk to go to as well.
cons: As a post-doc, you don't have any benefits; parking in the hospital is expensive, and you are always assgined to a parking lot far away from where you work. Salary for a starting post-doc is pretty low

pros: Great location. Some great fellow employees. Benefits (pension plan, health & dental, free tuition for self, spouse, dependents). Flexible schedule. Summer hours. Good cafeteria (open to employees), Sports complex access and reduced membership prices. Nice newer buildings for students and staff.  Good pay if above level 8 or above.
cons: Hi percentage of poor quality mid-level managers...may be nice people (or not) but have poor (or no) business and/or people management skills. Website accessibility very poor, nobody seems in charge.  Main campus difficult to get around if any mobility issues. Complaints of harassment, bullying etc. not dealt with effectively or in transparent way.  Rules apply to some but not others. Feels very bureaucratic. Innovative business practices seem very foreign concept to many in management. Very high turover.  IT systems seem pretty archaic, although efforts are being made to change this it seems. Communication between and within sectors and departments not very effective (employee-employee and employee-manager). Fair amount of back-stabbing among lower level employees in some departments. Employee evaluations done online and not very meaningful. Much of what happens seems like it's being done just so a box can be ticked off and butts covered. Executive level managers do a lot of micromanaging. Incompetent or ill equipped staff put in higher positions they aren't qualified for. Many permanent positions being abolished or filled with contract staff when current staff member leaves, making it hard for permanent staff to move up. Union seems to have no power even though collective agreement states members' work not to be farmed out on contract, etc. Union won't take a harassment complaint against another member.  Seem to be quite a lot of people off on stress leave at any given time. Signage (MAPS!) are poorly done and difficult to decipher (seem like developed by someone without experience in wayfinding).  Some people work like dogs, others have it nice and easy. Little team building or social activities among department members. Clock into cubicle. Clock out of cubicle.  PS. Michaëlle Jean left uOttawa in about 2015.

pros: There are some really great people in the department and top-notch research is conducted. Great work environment.
cons: HR and university administration is a complete mess. Issues include paperwork that goes missing or is not processed on time, people not getting paid on time due to admin errors. Also, 0 benefits for post-docs. You get your salary through your prof, and that's it - the university doesn't give you anything. You won't be in either the staff or student's union, so you better have private coverage.

pros: Excellent resources provided for both part-time and full-time teaching faculty e.g. Teaching Learning and Support Service (TLSS)
cons: Incumbency rules and "seniority points" prevent younger entrants in academia who want teaching experience from getting their foot in the door.

job_title: Software Development Manager in Ottawa, ON
pros: Got to speak to our users, and to propose new ideas. Got to prose and suggest new technologies. Got to work with many great people.
cons: Decision makers were not very technical, and they made terrible decisions. They resisted advice. There was a low level of trust that just wears you down after a while. Negative experience overall.

pros: Good facilities for teaching, including WiFI and wired classroom.  Good student body, that seems engaged.

As a whole, the administration seems to favour French as the language of choice so English speaking profs seem at a disadvantage.  The reliance on web based email is also frustrating.

cons: Shared basement office, outdated lab equipment, limited summer TA opportunities.
